script: DANIEL: Ladies and gentlemen, I've traveled over half our state to be here tonight.
I couldn't get away sooner because my new well was coming in at Coyote Hills, and I had to see about it.
That well is now flowing at 2,000 barrels, and it's paying me an income of $5,000 a week.
I have two others drilling, and I have 16 producing at Antelope.
So, ladies and gentlemen, if I say I'm an oilman, you will agree.
Now, you have a great chance here, but bear in mind you can lose it all if you're not careful.
Out of all men that beg for a chance to drill your lots, maybe one in 20 will be oilmen.
The rest will be speculators, that's men trying to get between you and the oilmen to get some of the money that ought, by rights, come to you.
Even if you find one that has money and means to drill, he'll maybe know nothing about drilling.
He'll have to hire the job out on contract, and then you're depending on a contractor, who'll rush the job through so he can get another contract just as quick as he can.
This is the way that this works.
MAN 1: Well, what is your offer?
And the men that work for me work for me, and they are men I know.
I make it my business to be there and to see their work.
I don't lose my tools in the hole and spend months fishing for them.
I don't botch the cementing off and let water in the hole and ruin the whole lease.
This is my son and my partner, H.W. Plainview.
We offer you the bond of family that very few oilmen can understand.
I'm fixed like no other company in this field, and that's because my Coyote Hills well has just come in.
I have a string of tools all ready to put to work.
I can load a rig onto trucks and have them here in a week.
I have business connections, so I can get the lumber for the derricks.
Such things go by friendship in a rush like this.
And this is why I can guarantee to start drilling and to put up the cash to back my word.
I assure you, ladies and gentlemen, no matter what the others promise to do, when it comes to the showdown, they won't be there.
Sit down, you have no right-- PRESCOTT: Let us discuss what the man has to say-- MAN: Prescott, you trust this man?
PRESCOTT: Discuss what he has to say.
There's logic to what he's saying.
MAN 2: We gain nothing by losing our heads!
Look at that well out there!
MAN 3: Nobody's losing their heads-- You have no business being here!
DANIEL: I don't need the lease.
PRESCOTT: But we need you to begin-- DANIEL: Too much confusion.
PRESCOTT: No, no. There's no confusion-- I wouldn't take the lease if you gave it to me as a gift.
DANIEL: Mr. Bankside, I'm not gonna waste your time.
I'd certainly appreciate it if you didn't waste mine.
Now, if you wish to sign with me, we can have a well drilling within ten days.
Your lot is further north from the discovery well up here, and so, well, that means we'll probably have to dig deeper.
And if there's as much oil here as I think there is, it'll be harder to reach, but once we find it, we can take it right out.
We have to act quickly, because very soon these fields'll be dry.
I need you to know what you wanna do.
Now, because of the distance from the discovery well, I'll pay you a smaller royalty than you'd get down there, but I'm prepared to give you a $1,000 bonus on your lot.
MR. BANKSIDE: What kind of royalty are you talking about?
One-sixth, plus a guarantee to start drilling within ten days.
Now, that's something you won't find anywhere else.
What age are your children, ma'am?
She died in childbirth, Mrs. Bankside, so, uh, it's just me and my son now.
OIL FIELD WORKER 1: It's coming in, boss!
OIL FIELD WORKER 2: You hear it?
What can I do for you?
What do you pay for a place that has it?
If I told you I knew a place that had oil where land could be bought cheaply, what do you think that would be worth?
...you should let me know what you know, and then we'll try and work something out.
What church do you belong to?
I don't belong to one church in particular.
That's what I wanna sell you.
What are you doing in Signal Hill?
We have oil, and it seeps through the ground.
Do you wanna pay me to know where it is?
Well, just because there's something on the ground doesn't mean there's anything beneath it.
Why did Standard Oil buy up land?
How much land did they buy?
I'd like it better if you didn't think I was stupid.
DANIEL: Why'd you come to me?
You just brought this well in.
Yes. So just give me $500 in cash right now, and I'll tell you where it is.
DANIEL: I'll tell you what I'll do, son.
I'll give you a hundred dollars now, and if it proves to be a promising lease, then give you a $1,000 bonus.
Just tell me one thing to help me decide.
What else have you got up there?
We have a big ranch, but it's mostly rocks.
What makes you think it's up?
You tell me something worth hearing, this money's yours.
I come from a town called Little Boston, in Isabella County.
Spur station here at Little Boston.
The Sunday ranch is what you're looking for.
There's a sheep trail that takes you there.
It's a mile out of town headed west. Not far.
Just through a small pass here, near the base of the hills.
You'll pass a church and just follow the sheep trail.
Your family name is Sunday, yes?
My father and mother and sisters and my brother Eli.
How many sisters do you have?
Does any of your family know about the oil you say is there?
My uncle always said there was oil there, but I don't know what they heard or what they think.
I told you, nothing grows but weeds.
You drill a well, it's hard not to get saltwater.
I want to go now, so...
No, uh, I wanna go now.
If I travel all the way out there and I find that you've been lying to me, I'm gonna find you and I'm gonna take more than my money back.
Is that all right with you?
We're told there might be a good place to camp up near the Sunday ranch.
We heard there was an earthquake up here a few days ago.
We have goat's milk, if you'd like.
if we set our tent away over there, we'd be out of your way over there.
Ruth, help these men and bring them some water.
Mr. Plainview, would you like that milk now?
My family will help you set up your tent.
No, please. We set ourselves on this camping trip.
We have to do the camping.
I'll have them boil you up some potatoes.
That's all right. I thought maybe we'd make a fire.
I wanted to work with my son on making a fire.
All right. My son Eli will bring you some wood.
Thank you so much for your hospitality, Mr. Sunday.
I'm sorry we don't have any bread.
Corn just doesn't fill out in the hills here.
We don't have room to raise the grain.
If there's anything here, we take it to the sea.
What we do is we build a pipeline to Port Hueneme or Santa Paula-- It's about a hundred miles-- and we do a deal with Union Oil.
Then we don't need the railroads and their shipping costs anymore.
We're making the real money that we should be making, not just-- Not just throwing it away on shipping costs.
How much are we gonna pay them?
Well, I'm not gonna give them oil prices.
If we could have a few minutes, there's something I'd very much like to talk with you about.
Mother, would you take the girls outside, please?
Well, uh, I believe in plain speaking, so...
My boy's been sick, you know.
Doctors all say he needs plentiful fresh air.
what would you say would be a fair price for this lot, Abel?
And with the improvements to the ranch over the years at $500-- I'd like to offer you $3,700 for this ranch.
The Lord has sent this man here, Eli.
What is it that brought you here, sir?
Now, of course, within that, we're gonna develop a lease.
Oh, do you have someone who can drill for it?
Do you think there's oil here?
You know, to get it up and out of the ground.
Well, our oil sits right up on top of the ground.
Doesn't necessarily mean there's anything underneath.
What would you give us for it?
if we decide to drill for oil, and if the well begins to produce, I'll give your church a $5,000 signing bonus.
Do you wanna find someone else that's gonna come up here and drill, Eli?
Make the investment and do all the hard work that goes into it?
I can just as easily hunt for quail on another ranch as I can here, so, uh-- Though I'll happily be a supporter of your church for as long as I can.
Now, as it happens, I do have some connections in the drilling business who might help get us started.
How do you feel about this, Abel?
Well, good. Let's draw up some contracts and let's-- Let's give it a try.
Appreciate your help with this, Eli.
I just bought the Sunday ranch.
And, uh, well, where's the map?
Where are the hills behind the Sunday ranch?
That's the Belvins, and that could be got, I'm sure.
Can everything around here be got?
Well, Paul Sunday turned out to be a good friend of ours.
Well, you get here just as soon as you can.
GENE: Pretty good. Where's your dad?
You fellas are a long way from Signal Hill.
You boys are a regular family business.
You boys are a little late.
Hmm. Did you hear Standard bought up?
Mostly in the north, so far.
If you're gonna make a play, look east.
I'd rather it be you than someone else, you know.
This mud around here has been taken.
It must be easy when you have such a cute face to carry around with you.
Telling me how handsome my son is?
I'll be your lawyer if you need to draw up a contract.
Make sure you don't get swindled, boy.
Get half what your dad's making.
They're just guys that are working for us.
How much money can we make?
Mary said that her father beats her if she doesn't pray.
Mary, she's the, uh, smaller one?
There were a few vacant lots and one holdout.
An old man who homesteaded here.
No, he'd like you to come visit with him.
He said he'd like to speak with whoever is doing the buying.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you so much for visiting with us this evening.
Well, I've traveled across half our state to be here and to see about this land.
DANIEL: Now, I daresay some of you might have heard some of the more extravagant rumors about what my plans are, so I just thought you'd like to hear it from me.
I have numerous concerns spread across this state.
I have many wells flowing at many thousand barrels per day, so I like to think of myself as an oilman.
As an oilman, I hope that you'll forgive just good old-fashioned plain speaking.
Now, this work that we do is very much a family enterprise.
Uh, I work side by side with my wonderful son, H.W.
I think one or two of you might have met him already.
And, uh, I encourage my men to bring their families as well.
Of course, it makes for an ever so much more rewarding life for them.
Family means children, and children means education.
So, wherever we set up camp, education is a necessity, and we're just so happy to take care of that.
So let's build a wonderful school in Little Boston.
These children are the future that we strive for, and so they should have the very best of things.
Now, something else, uh, and please don't be insulted if I speak about this: bread.
Now, to my mind, uh, it's an abomination to consider that any man, woman, or child in this magnificent country of ours should have to look upon a loaf of bread as a luxury.
We're gonna dig water wells here, and, uh, water wells means irrigation.
We're gonna raise crops here where before it just simply wasn't possible.
You'll have more grain than you'll know what to do with, and bread'll be coming right out of your ears, ma'am.

These are just a few of the things we can offer you, and I assure you, ladies and gentlemen, that if we do find oil here, and I think there's a very good chance that we will, this community of yours will not only survive, it will flourish.
I'd be happy to answer any questions that you might have.
Will the new road lead to the church?
Well, that'll be the first place that it leads.
Well, if anything comes up, I'm pretty easy to find.
You just come visit with me.
Thank you so much for your time, and good night.
CONGREGATION: ELI: Just follow the new road back to the church.
The new road will lead you there.
Hello, brother, my name is Eli.
The Church of the Third Revelation welcomes you.
Hello, brother, my name is Eli.
The Church of the Third Revelation welcomes you.
Just follow the new road right to the church.
CONGREGATION: Daniel, may I speak with you?
I'll bring them up when they arrive.
How is all the work coming?
All the men are provided for?
Is there anything that you need from me?
Anything the church can do for you?
I understand you've asked the people to gather around and watch the well begin tomorrow, is that right?
Before you begin, you should introduce me.
You'll see me walk up towards the oil well, and when I-- The derrick.
You'll see me walk up, and then you could say my name.
Yes. You'll see me walk up, and then you could say, The proud son of these hills who tended his Father's flock.
And then you could say my name.
Well, then we start the drill.
It's a simple blessing, Daniel, but an important one.
DANIEL: What time's good for you, Eli?
Well, let's make it four o'clock then.
I thank you all so much for visiting with us at this time.
I've had the pleasure of meeting some of you, and I hope very much in the months to come, I'll be able to visit with each and every one of you.
I'm better at digging holes in the ground than making speeches, so let's forget the speech for this evening, just make it a simple blessing.
You see, one man doesn't prospect from the ground.
It takes a whole community of good people, such as yourselves, and, uh, this is good.
We pray together, we work together, and if the Good Lord smiles kindly on our endeavor, we share in the wealth together.

Now, before we spud in Mary's Well Number One, named for the lovely Miss Mary Sunday here by my side, a proud daughter of these hills, I'd just like to say God bless these honest labors of ours, and of course God bless you all.
FLETCHER: Are you ready to do this?
Uh, Al Rose has very generously provided some refreshments for this occasion out of his own pocket.
If you'll all just care to help yourselves, I'll be back in a minute.
Now, do you like your new dress?
Are you happy I came here?
Your daddy doesn't hit you anymore, does he?
Go and play some more and don't come back.
Go on. Go back to sleep.
Lost a man down the well.
OIL FIELD WORKER 1: Set the brake.
FLETCHER: They're fishing it out now.
Anyone goes down into the cellar, you tell somebody.
ELI: I went to my room to thank God what he had given all of us.
Yes, last night, I had a vision, and I felt God's breath move through me.
And it rolled down into my stomach.
It sloshed around, and my stomach spoke in a whisper, not a shout.
Touch this woman with your hands and caress her.
My dear Mrs. Hunter, you have arthritis, don't you?
The devil is in your hands, and I will suck it out.
Now, I will not cast this ghost out with a fever, for the new spirit inside me has shown me I have a new way to communicate.
Don't you dare turn around and come back.
For if you do, all the armies of my boot will kick you in the teeth, and you will be cast up and thrown in the dirt and thrust back to perdition!
And as long as I have teeth, I will bite you, and if I have no teeth, I will gum you!
And as long as I have fists, I will bash you!
MAN: Praise the Lord and his holiness.
Tragedy at the well last night.
Joe Gundha was a man of considerable faith.
So if you wish to say a few words, his burial's at noon tomorrow.
Daniel, this accident could have been avoided.
It is terrible to think of that well-- Yes, it could have. These men work in 12-hour shifts.
If they don't have it, they make stupid mistakes.
I've seen some of the men drinking.
We need these men well-rested to bring in this well.
They can't get that if they're up here listening to your gospel, and then the well can't produce and blow gold all over the place.
I wish I had more time with Joe Gundha.
Then the well can't produce and blow gold all over the place.
Now, would you see to it that his personal possessions, uh, find their way back to his family, please?
Heard you were planning some renovations.
Yes, our congregation is growing strongly.
Well, that was one goddamn hell of a show.
We were happy to have you, Daniel.
Let go. Let go. You're safe.
Now, tell me where it hurts.
Tell me where-- Did you see this?
Were you hit in the head?
Were you hit in the head?
Tell me! You have to tell me if you were.
I have to go and deal with this now.
I'll be back in a minute.
I'm gonna take care of you.
FLETCHER: Gotta break the cables, Daniel!
Take Dave and two of the fellas up to the hole.
Don't wait till it gets too hot.
What are you looking so miserable about?
There's a whole ocean of oil under our feet!
No one can get at it except for me.
Who do we know in San Francisco or, um, Los Angeles, who could work with, uh...
You know, we could-- Someone, a teacher for H.W.
How could you figure out that?
FLETCHER: Bob Brody in San Francisco?
Call Bob Brody and get someone down here.
When do we get our money, Daniel?
And a vessel for the Holy Spirit?
When are you coming over and make my son hear again?
If you had let me bless the well this wouldn't have happened.
You owe the Church of the Third Revelation $5,000...
...as part of the arrangement that we made!
Don't even try it, you little runt!
I'm gonna bury you underground, Eli.
You are a stupid man, Abel.
You've let someone come in here and walk all over us.
You let him in and do his work here, and you are a stupid man for what we could have had.
You didn't do anything but sit down.
Do you think God is going to save you for being stupid?
He doesn't save stupid people, Abel.
ELI: I will tear you apart for what you've done, you stupid man!
Help. Son, don't do this-- Be quiet!
It was Paul who told him to come here.
He went to him and he said, My stupid, weak father will give away his lots.
A stupid father to a stupid son.
What can I do for you?
I read about your gusher in the paper, about your success.
I got a letter from Annabelle.
You came all the way from Wisconsin to tell me this?
Do you have this-- This letter?
Yes, I know, but from where?
I was, uh, trying drilling of my own for years.
I, uh, spent time in jail.
I had a stretch of very bad time.
I had nothing, was picked up in Louisiana.
I worked on a chain gang for six months building roads.
That-- That was a very hard time.
What were you in jail for?
Believe it or not, for all the terrible things I've gotten myself into, when they picked me up, I hadn't done anything.
But I've, uh, done my share of things that...
If you can spare something, I-- I can work for you in any way.
I know I'll keep moving, before long, to get back to Fond du Lac.
You say nothing, then you say you'd like to stay and work.
And it's better, I'd just like to hear you say you'd like to be here.
I worked cable tool rigs, built railroads.
DANIEL: What did my mother know?
I don't know if she knew and looked the other way, if she never knew.
I know you didn't get on with our father.
I worked for Geological Survey, and, uh, went to Kansas.
I don't like to explain myself.
Are you an angry man, Henry?
I have a competition in me.
I want no one else to succeed.
HENRY: That part of me is gone.
Well, if it's in me, it's in you.
There are times when I-- I look at people and I see nothing worth liking.
I wanna earn enough money I can get away from everyone.
What will you do about your boy?
Does your sound come back to you? I don't know.
I don't wanna talk about those things.
I see the worst in people, Henry.
I don't need to look past seeing them to get all I need.
I've built up my hatreds over the years, little by little, and...
Having you here gives me a second breath of life.
I can't keep doing this on my own.
Just have to go and have a word with the conductor.
This is my brother, Henry Plainview from Fond du Lac.
TILFORD: Is there anything we can do?
Is this about buying up my tracts here?
The cable was about my Coyote Hills lease.
DANIEL: What's your offer on Coyote Hills?
We'll offer a 150,000 for full title.
TILFORD: You have 11,000 acres in Little Boston.
You have one proven well that was damaged-- DANIEL: I have three wells proven.
TILFORD: We'll make you a millionaire while you're sitting here from one minute to the next.
And what else would I do with myself?
What else would I do with myself?
TILFORD: Take care of your son.
I don't know what you would do.
If you were me, and Standard offered to buy what you had for a million dollars, why?
DANIEL: Yeah, you fellas should just scratch around in the dirt and find it like the rest of us, instead of buying up someone else's hard work.
I've scratched around the dirt, son.
You gonna change your shipping costs?
TILFORD: Where are you gonna put it all?
Build a pipeline? Make a deal with Union Oil? Be my guest.
But if you can't pull it off, you've got an ocean of oil under your feet with nowhere to go.
Why not turn it over to us?
You spend time with your boy.
Did you just tell me how to run my family?
TILFORD: It might be more important now that you've proven the field, and we're offering to buy you out.
One night I'm going to come to you, inside of your house or wherever you're sleeping, and I'm gonna cut your throat.
What? What are you talking about?
TILFORD: I heard. Why did you say it?
You don't tell me about my son.
TILFORD: Why are you acting insane and threatening to cut my throat?
You don't tell me about my son.
TILFORD: I'm not telling you anything!
I'm asking you to be reasonable.
If I've offended you, I apologize.
You'll see what I can do.
This parcel here is the 3,000-acre ranch owned by B.L. Harper.
This is San Luis Obispo County land.
And from here to the coast, it's all Union Oil.
He was the holdout, when we were doing the buying.
He had hoped to speak with you.
Can't you just build the pipeline around this tract?
Can I build around 50 miles of Tehachapi mountains?
Don't be thick in front of me, Al.
I can go to him again.
No. I'll go and talk to the man.
Well, he's sharing with another boy.
He's been there for a year.
Are you taking Henry with you to meet Union Oil?
Are you the son of William Bandy?
I wanna talk with him about his property.
I believe I'll talk with him about that.
We don't want you drilling out here.
Well, I don't want it either.
Tell him I'd like to speak with him.
DANIEL: Put that one in a glass case.
Hundred miles of pipeline and all the independent producers of this great state.
DANIEL: There's that house in Fond du Lac that John Hollister built.
DANIEL: I thought as a boy that was the most beautiful house I'd ever seen, and I wanted it.
I wanted to live in it.
And even as a boy, I wanted to have children to run around in it.
You can have anything you'd like now, Daniel.
Where are you gonna build it?
Would you make it look like that house?
I think if I saw that house now, it'd make me sick.
We can eat and get some women.
Take them to the Peachtree dance.
I say get liquored up and take them to the Peachtree dance.
Can I have some money, please?
Can I have some money, please?
I want you to tell me something.
What's the name of the farm next to the Hill House?
What was the name of the farm next to the Hill House?
I-- I can't remember-- Who are you?
Just let me get up and go.
I met a man in King City who said he was your brother.
And he wanted to make his way to you, Daniel.
But he told me about you...
and I just took his story...
I'm not trying to hurt you.
Yeah, I'd like to lease your land.
I had asked for you to come and talk to me before.
My boy's been very sick, you know.
This was before your boy got sick.
Now, I know that you would like to build a pipeline through my property.
Is that right, what I've heard?
It could be buried with your consent.
I guarantee you absolutely no disruption-- God.
God has told me what you must do.
You should be washed in the blood of Jesus Christ.
I have been washed, Mr. Bandy.
It's your only way to salvation.
And your only way for what you want.
You can take it at the Church of the Third Revelation.
I'd like you to be part of our church.
Be forgiven for this sin that you've done.
What sin are you, uh, referring to, Mr. Bandy?
ELI: I truly wish everyone could be saved, don't you?
ELI: I am afraid that's just not the case.
The doctrine of universal salvation is a lie, is it not?
I wish everyone could be saved, but they won't.
You will never be saved if you...
Now, is there a sinner here looking for salvation?
Is there a sinner here looking for God?
ELI: Thank you for coming, Brother Daniel.
We have a sinner with us here who wishes for salvation.
Oh, the Lord can't hear you, Daniel.
Look up to the sky and say it.
Uh, what do you want me to say?
You've come here, and you've brought good and wealth, but you have also brought your bad habits as a backslider.
You've lusted after women, and you have abandoned your child.
Your child, that you raised, you have abandoned all because he was sick, and you have sinned.
ELI: I was lost, but now I am found.
I was lost, but now I'm found.
ELI: I have abandoned my child.
ELI: Now beg for the blood!
Give me the blood, Lord, and let me get away!
ELI: Do you accept Jesus Christ as your Lord and Savior?
I can feel the power of the Lord!
Do you accept the Church of the Third Revelation as your spiritual guide?
Do you accept Jesus Christ as your savior?
Welcome to the fold, Brother Plainview.
He must take the spirit in on his own.
ELI: Mr. Plainview has been generous enough to make a $5,000 donation to the church, which we are still waiting for.
Oh, you're too heavy for me.
FLETCHER: You wanna get something to eat?
All the way to the sea.
Let's take a look at you.
All right. That's it, that's it.
Let's get some decent food inside of you.
That's all we need here is a good, strong, expensive meal.
Two steaks, a whiskey, and water for him.
We're gonna have this teacher help you.
He's gonna help take care of all of this.
Got everything we need now to build this company.
I believe we ordered these drinks before those people.
I am sorry about that, sir.
I'll have your steaks right out.
TILFORD: That green turtle soup is fantastic.
So, uh, ahem, Standard offered us a million dollars for the Little Boston leases.
I told H.M. Tilford where he could shove that.
And we made a deal with Union.
And that whole ocean of oil underneath our fields.
MAN: Needed the money to drill.
I go out to meet him.
He's getting oil on the property.
We're trying to make a claim on it.
MAN 2: Orange fritters, mashed potatoes, green peas.
I want you to look over there.
Daniel, let me introduce-- Look over there. You see?
You don't tell me how to raise my family.
I told you not to tell me how to raise my family.
TILFORD: I'm very happy for you that the deal-- DANIEL: Yes, I made a deal with Union.
You look like a fool, don't you, Tilford?
I told you what I was gonna do.
Mr. Sunday. I understand you're leaving our fair community.
Yes, I'm going on a mission.
Oildale, Taft, and then on to Bakersfield.
MAN 1: Well, I want you to know that they're replacing you...
MAN 1: You done a great job for us.
MAN 1: I thank you very much.
JUDGE: Union Oil Company, Santa Paula, California.
The woman sayeth unto him, 'Sir, give me this water 'and I shall thirst not, neither come hither to draw.' Come in, come in.
GEORGE: I'd prefer to speak to you in private.
So why don't you flap your hands about and have what's-his-name tell me where you've been.
Or do you think I don't know?
GEORGE: This is hard for me to say.
I'll tell you first, I love you very much.
I've learned to love what I do because of you.
I'm taking Mary, and I'm going to Mexico.
It will only be for a time.
For me to do my own drilling...
It's time to make a change.
No. No, it's not like that.
You are making such a misstep.
GEORGE: I know you and I have disagreed over many things.
I'd rather keep you as my father than my partner.
You've got something to say to me then say it.
I'd like to hear you speak instead of your little dog.
Woof, woof, woof, woof, woof, woof, woof.
I'm going to Mexico with my wife.
That wasn't so hard, was it?
Killing us with what you're doing.
You're killing my image of you as my son.
I know you don't mean it.
Did you ever hear that word?
You operated here today like one.
I should have seen this coming.
under this all these past years, you've been building new hate for me piece by piece.
I don't even know who you are because you have none of me in you.
You're an orphan from a basket in the middle of the desert.

You have none of me in you.
You're just a bastard from a basket.
I thank God I have none of you in me.
Just a little piece of competition.
You're a bastard from a basket!
Mr. Daniel, you've got a visitor.
Daniel Plainview's house is on fire!
Oh, your home is a miracle.
I've been spreading his word far and wide.
Yes, so much, so much has been happening.
To be here and find you, and see you well is wonderful.
And we have a chance to catch up.
Things go up, things go down, but at least the Lord is always around.
We've seen ups and downs, haven't we?
Are things down for you right now, Eli?
But I do come with some sad news.
Mr. Bandy has passed on to the Lord.
He lived to be 99 years old, God bless him.
Have you met his grandson, William?
William Bandy is one of the finest members we have at the Church of the Third Revelation.
He is eager to come to Hollywood to be in movies.
And I do think he will have success.
Would you like me to speak with him?
Daniel, I'm asking if you'd like to have business with the Church of the Third Revelation in developing this lease on young Bandy's 1,000-acre tract.
I'm offering you to drill on one of the great undeveloped fields of Little Boston.
I'd be happy to work with you.
But there is one condition for this work.
I'd like you to tell me that you are a false prophet.
I'd like you to tell me that you are, and have been, a false prophet.
And that God is a superstition.
When can we begin to drill?
How long will it take to bring in the well?
I would like a $100,000 signing bonus, plus the five that is owed to me, with interest.
I am a false prophet, and God is a superstition.
If that's what you believe, then I will say it.
Say it like you mean it.
Say it like it's your sermon.
Just imagine this is your church here and, uh, you have a full congregation, so...
They can't hear you at the back.
Yes, it's, uh-- It's called drainage, Eli.
See, I own everything around it, so of course, uh, I get what's underneath it.
But there are no derricks there.
This is, uh, the Bandy tract.
I drink it up every day.
I drink the blood of Lamb from Bandy's tract.

The Lord sometimes challenges us, doesn't he, Eli?

I must, I must, I must, I must.

While we wait for his word!
Because you're not the chosen brother, Eli.

...that slithered out on your mother's filth.

and starts to drink your milkshake...
